comment._content:
"None of his predecessors did anything remotely close to what Lincoln did in terms of suspending human rights."

None of his predecessors were dealing with a civil war. The idea of business as usual, in a time when a major chunk of the country was trying to secede, violating the Union? Ridiculous.

Funny how people can't understand that in times of war, normal "rights" are removed. It's man against man, trying to take your LIFE -- how's that for a right removed? It's not a civilized thing, war. It totally abrogates the social contract and the most fundamental moral codes. This idea that there's an honorable way to conduct wars is asinine and shameful. It's what allows us to calmly enter into them in the first place, what allows us to be genuinely surprised that the whole endeavor isn't a neatly conducted game ... that makes it possible for anyone to be shocked that "civilians" are often put in harm's way. What? Is the horrid intent of war not clear? Does anyone think the human damage can really be contained to the poor pawns in uniform? Or that doing so would make the killing in any sense more morally just? Jesus help us, people are stupid. There are times when war is called for. But if you believe that, and enter into it, don't have on blinders.

By the way, the Union wasn't fighting to end slavery. The Union was fighting because those who wanted to preserve and spread the right to enslave, wanted to secede. The Union wanted the vast wealth of the natural resources in the south. They wanted to keep the contiguous land mass united. They couched it in terms of slavery, at times, because those were the terms by which secession was made. Yes, 18 months into the War, an emancipation proclamation was floated -- but emancipation would never have been a reason for war, on its own. Well, not from the Union offensive stance.

Ridiculous." In the war of 1812, foreign troops attacked and occupied Washington DC, setting the white house and Capitol on fire. The war wasn't on as large a scale as the civil war, but the idea that Lincoln was alone in facing an existential threat to the Union is unfounded. Lincoln's issue was that he suspended habeus corpus in areas with functional courts, well within union territory. he essentially short circuited a functional judicial system. was this necessary? i'm not sure. maybe. but it was certainly a power grab and set a precedent for a consolidation of executive power that continues to this day.

To pretend any other kinds of rights should be carefully handled, if the right to life is being systematically taken away, is a philosophically absurd notion. Just because during some wars we *have* maintained levels of continuity of our governmental systems, and maintained the everyday workings of the social contract, doesn't impress me as good. It impresses me as sick, that we were able to compartmentalize a very animalistic way of settling differences. Again -- a way sometimes necessary, but not to be confused with business as usual.

comment.author: 19959407@N00
comment._content:
We weren't invaded. It was in our midst, it was our own people, and not on clear-cut lines. Within the same households, both north and south, there was division. It would have been chaos to try to take the time to figure out who was or was not a traitor, by the long process of the law. You do your best with information at hand, when quick decisions must be made -- just as I'm sure there were men with guns on fields, unable to tell for sure who was the enemy. But you can't just stand there, and wait to figure it out. Again, being in the midst of a war isn't a good place to be.

It seems to me we've turned war into a codified, acceptable means of conflict resolution, by giving it rules and regulations in and of itself, and in seeking to continue all non-wartime rules and regulations just as they are in peacetime. We make it seem as if "war" is just part of the bigger picture, something that stands by itself, that shouldn't upset the normal fabric of life. I don't think that makes sense, morally or practically.

As a last point, since I come off sounding totally anti-war -- I'll reiterate that at times, I think it's called for. But that if it is, it should be understood, nothing and no one is safe. And again, they oughtn't be. If it's okay for anyone to die, than it should be reason enough for everyone to die -- it should only be done for reasons of survival in the first place, where your military and people would die anyway, if you didn't engage (i.e. your most basic resources are imminently threatened, your lives are directly threatened).

comment.author: 19959407@N00
comment._content:
Striatic,

We disagree about the Civil War being comparable to the Revolutionary War.

And as far as I see it, the law doesn't protect human rights. The law protects civil order. It's possible to do so in a way that hinders human rights, in fact. Our system is not one that does so, it's true that we seek to optimize human rights in the pursuit and maintenance of peace. But in a time of war, when one feels the populace is threatened, it may be that maintaining civil order and the safety of the majority, means there will be some whose human rights will be compromised. Not nice? Well, don't have a war. 

Lincoln didn't randomly take away rights of his own citizens. It seems he believed himself unable to secure the safety of the greater number, without suspending habeas corpus. As I understand it, he wasn't happy to act outside of the Constitutional provisions, he believed it to be a genuinely necessary matter of expediency. And in the context, I don't think it can be well argued that he was wrong. The men he sought to snare were not "his own," they were the enemy, among his own. I made the analogy above, I'll make it again: if you are in a battle, and you are going to judge the entire success in terms of losses by friendly fire, you ought not be in the battle in the first place. If you aren't ready to sacrifice yourselves a bit to quash the opponent, the opponent wasn't worth fighting. Lincoln believed the Union was worth preserving. He was in the fight to win. He sacrificed the lives of many, many men to do so. Did the possibility that a few of the suspected traitors he imprisoned and/or executed were innocent, weigh heavily on his mind? I've no idea. It had to have been balanced by the responsibility he felt to the entire Union, acknowledging the risk that real traitors would have posed to a great number of men.

It's not an exact science, this playing about with morality. That's what I'm saying -- once you're in a war, it's not as black and white as it is in peacetime. It's not that a leader has carte blanche to transgress the status quo altogether, but the truth is, the worst transgression against human rights is already in play: the systematic killing of others. Ostensibly, it is done for a "just" reason -- anyway, one you consider worth the sacrifice of others. And so Lincoln did, on the battlefield, and possibly, in the courtroom.

I never said “rights” had anything to do with keeping us from murdering each other. That little measure of co-existence owes to our individual guiding principles and ethics in addition to the proscriptions - and penalties - of the civil law, and moreover, at its heart, our innate fear that we may, in the process of attempting said murder, fail and invite mortal harm instead upon ourselves! It’s that animal instinct of self-preservation that helps us steer clear of dire situations like that, not rights. Now, admittedly, thoughtful reflection and discourse are valuable tools in avoiding mortal conflict once disagreement and resentment fester. At the negotiation table, however, where compromise is the watchword by which most conflicts are mitigated, then aren’t those so-called inalienable rights by definition compromised in the process, at least for someone? Take, for example, something as commonplace as the peaceful exchange between dissimilar nations of a commodity like oil. Fleets of tankers leave Middle Eastern shores on an almost daily basis, and we happily send them a tidy bouquet of promissory debt and everyone’s happy. Mostly. In the case of the S*udis, we periodically take our seat at an oaken table in lavish staterooms, armed with our material needs, our multicultural relativism, and our ability-forged-of-necessity to look the other way, and we’re able to initiate and perpetuate this peaceable exchange. Now, where do the ol’ inalienable rights come into play again?? I’m sorry – is this where noble civility and that dose of compromise I mentioned above conspire to ignore said rights? I mean, we certainly get to talk about it enough. We’ve gone back and forth many times here already, and enjoyably (admit it) at that, brandishing about philosophical points like so many ping pong balls. We’ve got the leisure time, the electricity, the connectivity, and actual hardware and so on to make it all happen. I would submit to you, that I bet if we even get hungry, there’s food in the refrigerator! (Pretty nice luxury.) Well, I’m sorry now to burst the proverbial bubble I’ve so recently constructed, but we’ve come away from that table with our rights intact, sure… we do it almost everyday. And what are those rights again? And where are those same rights for the S*udi woman that wants to – I don’t know - hop in her car and take a spin over to the local university where she can learn the language and maybe take a few classes in western philosophy, thereby enabling her to jump right on in on our philosophical musings? They’re not hers. We didn’t even bring them to the table. No one did. That’s reality, subjective and indifferent. So regarding the mere existence of inalienable rights, we therefore owe an enormous debt of gratitude and awe to a system that even enables us to think thus!!

I think that sometimes killing each other is necessary -- anyway, it's what we do -- and it would be absurd to let that mean that anarchy reigns over all other aspects of life. So we compartmentalize war, and stay as civil as we can, away from the front lines.

comment.author: 19959407@N00
comment._content: It is an amazing photograph. But it wasn't taken back in 1847 as a celebration of photography, nor is it shared here as such. It was significant then as it is significant now: as a piece of material history, specifically important because of the subject. I have discovered in the last four years here that flickr is not merely a place to discuss photography. Many of us also routinely discuss issues or feelings that are inspired by the photographs we see posted. Taking part in those discussions is completely voluntary. In this case, the discussion was prompted by an image of a politician; it was absolutely topical. And I disagree -- we are all politicians, or so Solon intended: we live in a democracy, where it is our right (some might say our responsibility) to actively discuss our political beliefs. One needn't take advantage of that freedom, or fulfill that responsibility, but I don't think it is appropriate to tell others to refrain from such interaction.
